1.verse: "These are the rules you shall lay before them.

2.verse: When you purchase a Hebrew slave, he is to serve you for six years, but in the seventh year he shall be given his freedom without cost.

3.verse: If he comes into service alone, he shall leave alone; if he comes with a wife, his wife shall leave with him.

4.verse: But if his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the woman and her children shall remain the master's property and the man shall leave alone.

5.verse: If, however, the slave declares, 'I am devoted to my master and my wife and children; I will not go free,'

6.verse: his master shall bring him to God and there, at the door or doorpost, he shall pierce his ear with an awl, thus keeping him as his slave forever.

7.verse: "When a man sells his daughter as a slave, she shall not go free as male slaves do.

8.verse: But if her master, who had destined her for himself, dislikes her, he shall let her be redeemed. He has no right to sell her to a foreigner, since he has broken faith with her.

9.verse: If he destines her for his son, he shall treat her like a daughter.

10.verse: If he takes another wife, he shall not withhold her food, her clothing, or her conjugal rights.

11.verse: If he does not grant her these three things, she shall be given her freedom absolutely, without cost to her.

12.verse: "Whoever strikes a man a mortal blow must be put to death.

13.verse: He, however, who did not hunt a man down, but caused his death by an act of God, may flee to a place which I will set apart for this purpose.

14.verse: But when a man kills another after maliciously scheming to do so, you must take him even from my altar and put him to death.

15.verse: Whoever strikes his father or mother shall be put to death.

16.verse: "A kidnaper, whether he sells his victim or still has him when caught, shall be put to death.

17.verse: "Whoever curses his father or mother shall be put to death.

18.verse: "When men quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or with his fist, not mortally, but enough to put him in bed,

19.verse: the one who struck the blow shall be acquitted, provided the other can get up and walk around with the help of his staff. Still, he must compensate him for his enforced idleness and provide for his complete cure.

20.verse: "When a man strikes his male or female slave with a rod so hard that the slave dies under his hand, he shall be punished.

21.verse: If, however, the slave survives for a day or two, he is not to be punished, since the slave is his own property.

22.verse: "When men have a fight and hurt a pregnant woman, so that she suffers a miscarriage, but no further injury, the guilty one shall be fined as much as the woman's husband demands of him, and he shall pay in the presence of the judges.

23.verse: But if injury ensues, you shall give life for life,

24.verse: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,

25.verse: burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.

26.verse: "When a man strikes his male or female slave in the eye and destroys the use of the eye, he shall let the slave go free in compensation for the eye.

27.verse: If he knocks out a tooth of his male or female slave, he shall let the slave go free in compensation for the tooth.

28.verse: "When an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox must be stoned; its flesh may not be eaten. The owner of the ox, however, shall go unpunished.

29.verse: But if an ox was previously in the habit of goring people and its owner, though warned, would not keep it in; should it then kill a man or a woman, not only must the ox be stoned, but its owner also must be put to death.

30.verse: If, however, a fine is imposed on him, he must pay in ransom for his life whatever amount is imposed on him.

31.verse: This law applies if it is a boy or a girl that the ox gores.

32.verse: But if it is a male or a female slave that it gores, he must pay the owner of the slave thirty shekels of silver, and the ox must be stoned.

33.verse: "When a man uncovers or digs a cistern and does not cover it over again, should an ox or an ass fall into it,

34.verse: the owner of the cistern must make good by restoring the value of the animal to its owner; the dead animal, however, he may keep.

35.verse: "When one man's ox hurts another's ox so badly that it dies, they shall sell the live ox and divide this money as well as the dead animal equally between them.

36.verse: But if it was known that the ox was previously in the habit of goring and its owner would not keep it in, he must make full restitution, an ox for an ox; but the dead animal he may keep. (v ) "When a man steals an ox or a sheep and slaughters or sells it, he shall restore five oxen for the one ox, and four sheep for the one sheep.

annotations.1: [1] Rules: judicial precedents to be used in settling questions of law and custom. This introductory phrase serves as the title of the following collection of civil and religious laws (Exodus 21-23) which is called in Exodus 24:7, the book of the covenant
annotations.2: [6] To God: to the sanctuary; or perhaps the phrase is to be rendered, "to the gods," in the sense of "to the judges." Cf Psalm 82:1. Since the expression "to have an open ear" meant "to obey," a pierced ear lobe was an ancient symbol of obedience. Cf Psalm 40:7
annotations.3: [8] Destined her: intended her as a wife of second rank
annotations.4: [23-25] This section is known as the lex talionis, the law of tit for tat. The purpose of this law was not merely the enforcement of rigorous justice, but also the prevention of greater penalties than would be just. Christ refers to this passage when he exhorts Christians to cede their lawful rights for the sake of charity. Cf Matthew 5:38-40

1.verse: The altar of holocausts was made of acacia wood, on a square, five cubits long and five cubits wide; its height was three cubits.

2.verse: At the four corners horns were made that sprang directly from the altar. The whole was plated with bronze.

3.verse: All the utensils of the altar, the pots, shovels, basins, forks and fire pans, were likewise made of bronze.

4.verse: A grating of bronze network was made for the altar and placed round it, on the ground, half as high as the altar itself.

5.verse: Four rings were cast for the four corners of the bronze grating, as holders for the poles,

6.verse: which were made of acacia wood and plated with bronze.

7.verse: The poles were put through the rings on the sides of the altar for carrying it. The altar was made in the form of a hollow box.

8.verse: The bronze laver, with its bronze base, was made from the mirrors of the women who served at the entrance of the meeting tent.

9.verse: The court was made as follows. On the south side of the court there were hangings, woven of fine linen twined, a hundred cubits long,

10.verse: with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze, the hooks and bands of the columns being of silver.

11.verse: On the north side there were similar hangings, one hundred cubits long, with twenty columns and twenty pedestals of bronze, the hooks and bands of the columns being of silver.

12.verse: On the west side there were hangings, fifty cubits long, with ten columns and ten pedestals, the hooks and bands of the columns being of silver.

13.verse: On the east side the court was fifty cubits long.

14.verse: Toward one side there were hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals; toward the other side,

15.verse: beyond the entrance of the court, there were likewise hangings to the extent of fifteen cubits, with three columns and three pedestals.

16.verse: The hangings on all sides of the court were woven of fine linen twined.

17.verse: The pedestals of the columns were of bronze, while the hooks and bands of the columns were of silver; the capitals were silver-plated, and all the columns of the court were banded with silver.

18.verse: At the entrance of the court there was a variegated curtain, woven of violet, purple and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined, twenty cubits long and five cubits wide, in keeping with the hangings of the court.

19.verse: There were four columns and four pedestals of bronze for it, while their hooks were of silver.

20.verse: All the tent pegs for the Dwelling and for the court around it were of bronze.

21.verse: The following is an account of the various amounts used on the Dwelling, the Dwelling of the commandments, drawn up at the command of Moses by the Levites under the direction of Ithamar, son of Aaron the priest.

22.verse: However, it was Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, who made all that the Lord commanded Moses,

23.verse: and he was assisted by Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, who was an engraver, an embroiderer, and a weaver of variegated cloth of violet, purple and scarlet yarn and of fine linen.

24.verse: All the gold used in the entire construction of the sanctuary, having previously been given as an offering, amounted to twenty-nine talents and seven hundred and thirty shekels, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel.

25.verse: The amount of the silver received from the community was one hundred talents and one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five shekels, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel;

26.verse: one bekah apiece, that is, a half-shekel apiece, according to the standard of the sanctuary shekel, was received from every man of twenty years or more who entered the registered group; the number of these was six hundred and three thousand five hundred and fifty men.

27.verse: One hundred talents of silver were used for casting the pedestals of the sanctuary and the pedestals of the veil, one talent for each pedestal, or one hundred talents for the one hundred pedestals.

28.verse: The remaining one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five shekels were used for making the hooks on the columns, for plating the capitals, and for banding them with silver.

29.verse: The bronze, given as an offering, amounted to seventy talents and two thousand four hundred shekels.

30.verse: With this were made the pedestals at the entrance of the meeting tent, the bronze altar with its bronze gratings and all the appurtenances of the altar,

31.verse: the pedestals around the court, the pedestals at the entrance of the court, and all the tent pegs for the Dwelling and for the court around it.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: "See, I have chosen Bezalel, son of Uri, son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah,

3.verse: and I have filled him with a divine spirit of skill and understanding and knowledge in every craft:

4.verse: in the production of embroidery, in making things of gold, silver or bronze,

5.verse: in cutting and mounting precious stones, in carving wood, and in every craft.

6.verse: As his assistant I have appointed Oholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan. I have also endowed all the experts with the necessary skill to make all the things I have ordered you to make:

7.verse: the meeting tent, the ark of the commandments with the propitiatory on top of it, all the furnishings of the tent,

8.verse: the table with its appurtenances, the pure gold lampstand with all its appurtenances, the altar of incense,

9.verse: the altar of holocausts with all its appurtenances, the laver with its base,

10.verse: the service cloths, the sacred vestments for Aaron the priest, the vestments for his sons in their ministry,

11.verse: the anointing oil, and the fragrant incense for the sanctuary. All these things they shall make just as I have commanded you."

12.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

13.verse: "You must also tell the Israelites: Take care to keep my sabbaths, for that is to be the token between you and me throughout the generations, to show that it is I, the LORD, who make you holy.

14.verse: Therefore, you must keep the sabbath as something sacred. Whoever desecrates it shall be put to death. If anyone does work on that day, he must be rooted out of his people.

15.verse: Six days there are for doing work, but the seventh day is the sabbath of complete rest, sacred to the LORD. Anyone who does work on the sabbath day shall be put to death.

16.verse: So shall the Israelites observe the sabbath, keeping it throughout their generations as a perpetual covenant.

17.verse: Between me and the Israelites it is to be an everlasting token; for in six days the LORD made the heavens and the earth, but on the seventh day he rested at his ease."

18.verse: When the LORD had finished speaking to Moses on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two tablets of the commandments, the stone tablets inscribed by God's own finger.

1.verse: Now a certain man of the house of Levi married a Levite woman,

2.verse: who conceived and bore a son. Seeing that he was a goodly child, she hid him for three months.

3.verse: When she could hide him no longer, she took a papyrus basket, daubed it with bitumen and pitch, and putting the child in it, placed it among the reeds on the river bank.

4.verse: His sister stationed herself at a distance to find out what would happen to him.

5.verse: Pharaoh's daughter came down to the river to bathe, while her maids walked along the river bank. Noticing the basket among the reeds, she sent her handmaid to fetch it.

6.verse: On opening it, she looked, and lo, there was a baby boy, crying! She was moved with pity for him and said, "It is one of the Hebrews' children."

7.verse: Then his sister asked Pharaoh's daughter, "Shall I go and call one of the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?"

8.verse: "Yes, do so," she answered. So the maiden went and called the child's own mother.

9.verse: Pharaoh's daughter said to her, "Take this child and nurse it for me, and I will repay you." The woman therefore took the child and nursed it.

10.verse: When the child grew, she brought him to Pharaoh's daughter, who adopted him as her son and called him Moses; for she said, "I drew him out of the water."

11.verse: On one occasion, after Moses had grown up, when he visited his kinsmen and witnessed their forced labor, he saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew, one of his own kinsmen.

12.verse: Looking about and seeing no one, he slew the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.

13.verse: The next day he went out again, and now two Hebrews were fighting! So he asked the culprit, "Why are you striking your fellow Hebrew?"

14.verse: But he replied, "Who has appointed you ruler and judge over us? Are you thinking of killing me as you killed the Egyptian?" Then Moses became afraid and thought, "The affair must certainly be known."

15.verse: Pharaoh, too, heard of the affair and sought to put him to death. But Moses fled from him and stayed in the land of Midian. As he was seated there by a well,

16.verse: seven daughters of a priest of Midian came to draw water and fill the troughs to water their father's flock.

17.verse: But some shepherds came and drove them away. Then Moses got up and defended them and watered their flock.

18.verse: When they returned to their father Reuel, he said to them, "How is it you have returned so soon today?"

19.verse: They answered, "An Egyptian saved us from the interference of the shepherds. He even drew water for us and watered the flock!"

20.verse: "Where is the man?" he asked his daughters. "Why did you leave him there? Invite him to have something to eat."

21.verse: Moses agreed to live with him, and the man gave him his daughter Zipporah in marriage.

22.verse: She bore him a son, whom he named Gershom; for he said, "I am a stranger in a foreign land."

23.verse: A long time passed, during which the king of Egypt died. Still the Israelites groaned and cried out because of their slavery. As their cry for release went up to God,

24.verse: he heard their groaning and was mindful of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

25.verse: He saw the Israelites and knew..

annotations.1: [3] Basket: literally, "chest" or "ark"; the same Hebrew word is used in Genesis 6:14 for Noah's ark. Here, however, the chest was made of papyrus stalks
annotations.2: [10] When the child grew: probably when he was weaned or a little later. Moses: in Hebrew, Mosheh; the Hebrew word for "draw out" is mashah. This explanation of the name is not intended as a scientific etymology but as a play on words. The name is probably derived from an Egyptian word for "has been born," referring the birth to a god thought to be its sponsor
annotations.3: [11] After Moses had grown up: Acts 7:23 indicates that this was after an interval of nearly forty years. Cf Exodus 7:7. Striking: probably in the sense of "flogging"; according to some, "slaying.&quot
annotations.4: [18] Reuel: he was also called Jethro. Cf Exodus 3:1; 4:18; 18:1
annotations.5: [19] An Egyptian: Moses was probably wearing Egyptian dress, or spoke Egyptian to Reuel's daughters
annotations.6: [22] Gershom: the name is explained as if it came from the Hebrew word ger, "stranger," joined to the Hebrew word sham, "there." Some Greek and Latin manuscripts add here a passage taken from Exodus 18:4.

1.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,

2.verse: "This month shall stand at the head of your calendar; you shall reckon it the first month of the year.

3.verse: Tell the whole community of Israel: On the tenth of this month every one of your families must procure for itself a lamb, one apiece for each household.

4.verse: If a family is too small for a whole lamb, it shall join the nearest household in procuring one and shall share in the lamb in proportion to the number of persons who partake of it.

5.verse: The lamb must be a year-old male and without blemish. You may take it from either the sheep or the goats.

6.verse: You shall keep it until the fourteenth day of this month, and then, with the whole assembly of Israel present, it shall be slaughtered during the evening twilight.

7.verse: They shall take some of its blood and apply it to the two doorposts and the lintel of every house in which they partake of the lamb.

8.verse: That same night they shall eat its roasted flesh with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

9.verse: It shall not be eaten raw or boiled, but roasted whole, with its head and shanks and inner organs.

10.verse: None of it must be kept beyond the next morning; whatever is left over in the morning shall be burned up.

11.verse: "This is how you are to eat it: with your loins girt, sandals on your feet and your staff in hand, you shall eat like those who are in flight. It is the Passover of the LORD.

12.verse: For on this same night I will go through Egypt, striking down every first - born of the land, both man and beast, and executing judgment on all the gods of Egypt-I, the LORD!

13.verse: But the blood will mark the houses where you are. Seeing the blood, I will pass over you; thus, when I strike the land of Egypt, no destructive blow will come upon you.

14.verse: "This day shall be a memorial feast for you, which all your generations shall celebrate with pilgrimage to the LORD, as a perpetual institution.

15.verse: For seven days you must eat unleavened bread. From the very first day you shall have your houses clear of all leaven. Whoever eats leavened bread from the first day to the seventh shall be cut off from Israel.

16.verse: On the first day you shall hold a sacred assembly, and likewise on the seventh. On these days you shall not do any sort of work, except to prepare the food that everyone needs.

17.verse: "Keep, then, this custom of the unleavened bread. Since it was on this very day that I brought your ranks out of the land of Egypt, you must celebrate this day throughout your generations as a perpetual institution.

18.verse: From the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month until the evening of the twenty-first day of this month you shall eat unleavened bread.

19.verse: For seven days no leaven may be found in your houses. Anyone, be he a resident alien or a native, who eats leavened food shall be cut off from the community of Israel.

20.verse: Nothing leavened may you eat; wherever you dwell you may eat only unleavened bread."

21.verse: Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, "Go and procure lambs for your families, and slaughter them as Passover victims.

22.verse: Then take a bunch of hyssop, and dipping it in the blood that is in the basin, sprinkle the lintel and the two doorposts with this blood. But none of you shall go outdoors until morning.

23.verse: For the LORD will go by, striking down the Egyptians. Seeing the blood on the lintel and the two doorposts, the LORD will pass over that door and not let the destroyer come into your houses to strike you down.

24.verse: "You shall observe this as a perpetual ordinance for yourselves and your descendants.

25.verse: Thus, you must also observe this rite when you have entered the land which the LORD will give you as he promised.

26.verse: When your children ask you, 'What does this rite of yours mean?'

27.verse: you shall reply, 'This is the Passover sacrifice of the LORD, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt; when he struck down the Egyptians, he spared our houses.'" Then the people bowed down in worship,

28.verse: and the Israelites went and did as the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron.

29.verse: At midnight the LORD slew every first-born in the land of Egypt, from the first-born of Pharaoh on the throne to the first-born of the prisoner in the dungeon, as well as all the first-born of the animals.

30.verse: Pharaoh arose in the night, he and all his servants and all the Egyptians; and there was loud wailing throughout Egypt, for there was not a house without its dead.

31.verse: During the night Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, "Leave my people at once, you and the Israelites with you! Go and worship the LORD as you said.

32.verse: Take your flocks, too, and your herds, as you demanded, and be gone; and you will be doing me a favor."

33.verse: The Egyptians likewise urged the people on, to hasten their departure from the land; they thought that otherwise they would all die.

34.verse: The people, therefore, took their dough before it was leavened, in their kneading bowls wrapped in their cloaks on their shoulders.

35.verse: The Israelites did as Moses had commanded: they asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and gold and for clothing.

36.verse: The LORD indeed had made the Egyptians so well-disposed toward the people that they let them have whatever they asked for. Thus did they despoil the Egyptians.

37.verse: The Israelites set out from Rameses for Succoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, not counting the children.

38.verse: A crowd of mixed ancestry also went up with them, besides their livestock, very numerous flocks and herds.

39.verse: Since the dough they had brought out of Egypt was not leavened, they baked it into unleavened loaves. They had been rushed out of Egypt and had no opportunity even to prepare food for the journey.

40.verse: The time the Israelites had stayed in Egypt was four hundred and thirty years.

41.verse: At the end of four hundred and thirty years, all the hosts of the LORD left the land of Egypt on this very date.

42.verse: This was a night of vigil for the LORD, as he led them out of the land of Egypt; so on this same night all the Israelites must keep a vigil for the LORD throughout their generations.

43.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron, "These are the regulations for the Passover. No foreigner may partake of it.

44.verse: However, any slave who has been bought for money may partake of it, provided you have first circumcised him.

45.verse: But no transient alien or hired servant may partake of it.

46.verse: It must be eaten in one and the same house; you may not take any of its flesh outside the house. You shall not break any of its bones.

47.verse: The whole community of Israel must keep this feast.

48.verse: If any aliens living among you wish to celebrate the Passover of the LORD, all the males among them must first be circumcised, and then they may join in its observance just like the natives. But no man who is uncircumcised may partake of it.

49.verse: The law shall be the same for the resident alien as for the native."

50.verse: All the Israelites did just as the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron.

51.verse: On that same day the LORD brought the Israelites out of Egypt company by company.

annotations.1: [2] This month: Abib, the month of "ripe grain." Cf Exodus 13:4; 23:15; 34:18; Deut 16:1. It occurred near the vernal equinox, March-April. Later it was known by the Babylonian name of Nisan. Cf Nehemiah 2:1; Esther 5:7
annotations.2: [4] Share in the lamb: probably, in the expenses of its purchase. Some explain, "reckon for the lamb the number of persons required to eat it." Cf Exodus 12:10
annotations.3: [11] Passover: in Hebrew, pesach, in Aramaic, pascha. In the following verses the same root is used in the verb "to pass over." The word may be originally Egyptian, pesach, "the blow," i.e., the final plague which destroyed the Egyptian first-born
annotations.4: [22] Hyssop: a plant with many woody branchlets that made a convenient sprinkler
annotations.5: [38] Mixed ancestry: half-Hebrew and half-Egyptian. Cf Numbers 11:4; Lev 24:10-11
annotations.6: [40] In Egypt: according to some ancient sources, "in Canaan and Egypt," thus reckoning from the time of Abraham. Cf Gal 3:17
annotations.7: [46] You shall not break any of its bones: the application of these words to our Lord on the cross shows that the Paschal lamb was a prophetic type of Christ, immolated to free men from the bondage of sin. Cf also 1 Cor 5:7; 1 Peter 1:19.

1.verse: "(If a thief is caught in the act of housebreaking and beaten to death, there is no bloodguilt involved.

2.verse: But if after sunrise he is thus beaten, there is bloodguilt.) He must make full restitution. If he has nothing, he shall be sold to pay for his theft.

3.verse: If what he stole is found alive in his possession, be it an ox, an ass or a sheep, he shall restore two animals for each one stolen.

4.verse: "When a man is burning over a field or a vineyard, if he lets the fire spread so that it burns in another's field, he must make restitution with the best produce of his own field or vineyard.

5.verse: If the fire spreads further, and catches on to thorn bushes, so that shocked grain or standing grain or the field itself is burned up, the one who started the fire must make full restitution.

6.verse: "When a man gives money or an article to another for safekeeping and it is stolen from the latter's house, the thief, if caught, must make twofold restitution.

7.verse: If the thief is not caught, the owner of the house shall be brought to God, to swear that he himself did not lay hands on his neighbor's property.

8.verse: In every question of dishonest appropriation, whether it be about an ox, or an ass, or a sheep, or a garment, or anything else that has disappeared, where another claims that the thing is his, both parties shall present their case before God; the one whom God convicts must make twofold restitution to the other.

9.verse: "When a man gives an ass, or an ox, or a sheep, or any other animal to another for safekeeping, if it dies, or is maimed or snatched away, without anyone witnessing the fact,

10.verse: the custodian shall swear by the LORD that he did not lay hands on his neighbor's property; the owner must accept the oath, and no restitution is to be made.

11.verse: But if the custodian is really guilty of theft, he must make restitution to the owner.

12.verse: If it has been killed by a wild beast, let him bring it as evidence, and he need not make restitution for the mangled animal.

13.verse: "When a man borrows an animal from his neighbor, if it is maimed or dies while the owner is not present, the man must make restitution.

14.verse: But if the owner is present, he need not make restitution. If it was hired, this was covered by the price of its hire.

15.verse: "When a man seduces a virgin who is not betrothed, and lies with her, he shall pay her marriage price and marry her.

16.verse: If her father refuses to give her to him, he must still pay him the customary marriage price for virgins.

17.verse: "You shall not let a sorceress live.

18.verse: "Anyone who lies with an animal shall be put to death.

19.verse: "Whoever sacrifices to any god, except to the LORD alone, shall be doomed.

20.verse: "You shall not molest or oppress an alien, for you were once aliens yourselves in the land of Egypt.

21.verse: You shall not wrong any widow or orphan.

22.verse: If ever you wrong them and they cry out to me, I will surely hear their cry.

23.verse: My wrath will flare up, and I will kill you with the sword; then your own wives will be widows, and your children orphans.

24.verse: "If you lend money to one of your poor neighbors among my people, you shall not act like an extortioner toward him by demanding interest from him.

25.verse: If you take your neighbor's cloak as a pledge, you shall return it to him before sunset;

26.verse: for this cloak of his is the only covering he has for his body. What else has he to sleep in? If he cries out to me, I will hear him; for I am compassionate.

27.verse: "You shall not revile God, nor curse a prince of your people.

28.verse: "You shall not delay the offering of your harvest and your press. You shall give me the first-born of your sons.

29.verse: You must do the same with your oxen and your sheep; for seven days the firstling may stay with its mother, but on the eighth day you must give it to me.

30.verse: "You shall be men sacred to me. Flesh torn to pieces in the field you shall not eat; throw it to the dogs.

annotations.1: [1-2] If a thief is caught: this seems to be a fragment of what was once a longer law on housebreaking, which has been inserted here into the middle of a law on stealing animals. At night the householder would be justified in killing a burglar outright, but not so in the daytime, when the burglar could more easily be caught alive. He must make full restitution: this stood originally immediately after Exodus 21:37
annotations.2: [4] The Greek and Latin versions understood this verse as a prohibition against allowing one's cattle to graze in the field of another
annotations.3: [7] Brought to God: see note on Exodus 21:6. Cf also Exodus 22:10
annotations.4: [16] The customary marriage price for virgins: fifty shekels according to Deut 22:29
annotations.5: [27] God: or perhaps "the gods," in the sense of "the judges," as the parallel with a prince of your people suggests.

2.verse: God also said to Moses, "I am the LORD.

3.verse: As God the Almighty I appeared to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, but my name, LORD, I did not make known to them.

4.verse: I also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land in which they were living as aliens.

5.verse: And now that I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are treating as slaves, I am mindful of my covenant.

6.verse: Therefore, say to the Israelites: I am the LORD. I will free you from the forced labor of the Egyptians and will deliver you from their slavery. I will rescue you by my outstretched arm and with mighty acts of judgment.

7.verse: I will take you as my own people, and you shall have me as your God. You will know that I, the LORD, am your God when I free you from the labor of the Egyptians

8.verse: and bring you into the land which I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. I will give it to you as your own possession - I, the LORD!"

9.verse: But when Moses told this to the Israelites, they would not listen to him because of their dejection and hard slavery.

10.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses,

11.verse: "Go and tell Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to let the Israelites leave his land."

12.verse: But Moses protested to the LORD, "If the Israelites would not listen to me, how can it be that Pharaoh will listen to me, poor speaker that I am!"

13.verse: Still, the LORD, to bring the Israelites out of Egypt, spoke to Moses and Aaron and gave them his orders regarding both the Israelites and Pharaoh, king of Egypt.

14.verse: These are the heads of the ancestral houses. The sons of Reuben, the first-born of Israel, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron and Carmi; these are the clans of Reuben.

15.verse: The sons of Simeon were Jenuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar and Shaul, who was the son of a Canaanite woman; these are the clans of Simeon.

16.verse: The names of the sons of Levi, in their genealogical order, are Gershon, Kohath and Merari. Levi lived one hundred and thirty-seven years.

17.verse: The sons of Gershon, as heads of clans, were Libni and Shimei.

18.verse: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel. Kohath lived one hundred and thirty-three years.

19.verse: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of Levi in their genealogical order.

20.verse: Amram married his aunt Jochebed, who bore him Aaron, Moses and Miriam. Amram lived one hundred and thirty-seven years.

21.verse: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg and Zichri.

22.verse: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan and Sithri.

23.verse: Aaron married Amminadab's daughter, Elisheba, the sister of Nahshon; she bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.

24.verse: The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah and Abiasaph. These are the clans of the Korahites.

25.verse: Aaron's son, Eleazar, married one of Putiel's daughters, who bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the ancestral clans of the Levites.

26.verse: This is the Aaron and this the Moses to whom the LORD said, "Lead the Israelites from the land of Egypt, company by company."

27.verse: These are the ones who spoke to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to bring the Israelites out of Egypt - the same Moses and Aaron.

28.verse: On the day the LORD spoke to Moses in Egypt

29.verse: he said, "I am the LORD. Repeat to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, all that I tell you."

30.verse: But Moses protested to the LORD, "Since I am a poor speaker, how can it be that Pharaoh will listen to me?"

annotations.1: [14] The purpose of the genealogy here is to give the line from which Moses and Aaron sprang. Reuben and Simeon are first mentioned because, as older brothers of Levi, their names occur before his in the genealogy
annotations.2: [20] His aunt: more exactly, "his father's sister." Later on such a marriage was forbidden. Cf Lev 18:12. Hence, the Greek and Latin versions render here, "his cousin."

1.verse: The LORD spoke to Moses and said,

2.verse: "Consecrate to me every first-born that opens the womb among the Israelites, both of man and beast, for it belongs to me."

3.verse: Moses said to the people, "Remember this day on which you came out of Egypt, that place of slavery. It was with a strong hand that the LORD brought you away. Nothing made with leaven must be eaten.

4.verse: This day of your departure is in the month of Abib.

5.verse: Therefore, it is in this month that you must celebrate this rite, after the LORD, your God, has brought you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites and Jebusites, which he swore to your fathers he would give you, a land flowing with milk and honey.

6.verse: For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, and the seventh day shall also be a festival to the LORD.

7.verse: Only unleavened bread may be eaten during the seven days; no leaven and nothing leavened may be found in all your territory.

8.verse: On this day you shall explain to your son, 'This is because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.'

9.verse: It shall be as a sign on your hand and as a reminder on your forehead; thus the law of the LORD will ever be on your lips, because with a strong hand the LORD brought you out of Egypt.

10.verse: Therefore, you shall keep this prescribed rite at its appointed time from year to year.

11.verse: "When the LORD, your God, has brought you into the land of the Canaanites, which he swore to you and your fathers he would give you,

12.verse: you shall dedicate to the LORD every son that opens the womb; and all the male firstlings of your animals shall belong to the LORD.

13.verse: Every first-born of an ass you shall redeem with a sheep. If you do not redeem it, you shall break its neck. Every first-born son you must redeem.

14.verse: If your son should ask you later on, 'What does this mean?' you shall tell him, 'With a strong hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt, that place of slavery.

15.verse: When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the LORD killed every first-born in the land of Egypt, every first-born of man and of beast. That is why I sacrifice to the LORD everything of the male sex that opens the womb, and why I redeem every first-born of my sons.'

16.verse: Let this, then, be as a sign on your hand and as a pendant on your forehead: with a strong hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt."

17.verse: Now, when Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them by way of the Philistines' land, though this was the nearest; for he thought, should the people see that they would have to fight, they might change their minds and return to Egypt.

18.verse: Instead, he rerouted them toward the Red Sea by way of the desert road. In battle array the Israelites marched out of Egypt.

19.verse: Moses also took Joseph's bones along, for Joseph had made the Israelites swear solemnly that, when God should come to them, they would carry his bones away with them.

20.verse: Setting out from Succoth, they camped at Etham near the edge of the desert.

21.verse: The LORD preceded them, in the daytime by means of a column of cloud to show them the way, and at night by means of a column of fire to give them light. Thus they could travel both day and night.

22.verse: Neither the column of cloud by day nor the column of fire by night ever left its place in front of the people.

annotations.1: [17] By way of the Philistines' land: the most direct route from Egypt to Palestine, along the shore of the Mediterranean
annotations.2: [21] A column of cloud . . . a column of fire: probably one and the same preternatural phenomenon, a central nucleus of fire surrounded by smoke; only at night was its luminous nature visible. Cf Exodus 40:38.

1.verse: Moses himself was told, "Come up to the LORD, you and Aaron, with Nadab, Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel. You shall all worship at some distance,

2.verse: but Moses alone is to come close to the LORD; the others shall not come too near, and the people shall not come up at all with Moses."

3.verse: When Moses came to the people and related all the words and ordinances of the LORD, they all answered with one voice, "We will do everything that the LORD has told us."

4.verse: Moses then wrote down all the words of the LORD and, rising early the next day, he erected at the foot of the mountain an altar and twelve pillars for the twelve tribes of Israel.

5.verse: Then, having sent certain young men of the Israelites to offer holocausts and sacrifice young bulls as peace offerings to the LORD,

6.verse: Moses took half of the blood and put it in large bowls; the other half he splashed on the altar.

7.verse: Taking the book of the covenant, he read it aloud to the people, who answered, "All that the LORD has said, we will heed and do."

8.verse: Then he took the blood and sprinkled it on the people, saying, "This is the blood of the covenant which the LORD has made with you in accordance with all these words of his."

9.verse: Moses then went up with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and seventy elders of Israel,

10.verse: and they beheld the God of Israel. Under his feet there appeared to be sapphire tilework, as clear as the sky itself.

11.verse: Yet he did not smite these chosen Israelites. After gazing on God, they could still eat and drink.

12.verse: The LORD said to Moses, "Come up to me on the mountain and, while you are there, I will give you the stone tablets on which I have written the commandments intended for their instruction."

13.verse: So Moses set out with Joshua, his aide, and went up to the mountain of God.

14.verse: The elders, however, had been told by him, "Wait here for us until we return to you. Aaron and Hur are staying with you. If anyone has a complaint, let him refer the matter to them."

15.verse: After Moses had gone up, a cloud covered the mountain.

16.verse: The glory of the LORD settled upon Mount Sinai. The cloud covered it for six days, and on the seventh day he called to Moses from the midst of the cloud.

17.verse: To the Israelites the glory of the LORD was seen as a consuming fire on the mountaintop.

18.verse: But Moses passed into the midst of the cloud as he went up on the mountain; and there he stayed for forty days and forty nights.

annotations.1: [4] Pillars: stone shafts or slabs, erected as symbols of the fact that each of the twelve tribes had entered into this covenant with God; not idolatrous as in Exodus 23:24, although the same Hebrew word is used in both passages. See note on Genesis 28:18
annotations.2: [11] After gazing on God: the ancients thought that the sight of God would bring instantaneous death. Cf Exodus 33:20; Genesis 16:13; 32:31; Judges 6:22, 23; 13:22. Eat and drink: partake of the sacrificial meal.

1.verse: These are the names of the sons of Israel who, accompanied by their households, migrated with Jacob into Egypt:

2.verse: Reuben, Simeon, Levi and Judah;

3.verse: Issachar, Zebulun and Benjamin;

4.verse: Dan and Naphtali; Gad and Asher.

5.verse: The total number of the direct descendants of Jacob was seventy. Joseph was already in Egypt.

6.verse: Now Joseph and all his brothers and that whole generation died.

7.verse: But the Israelites were fruitful and prolific. They became so numerous and strong that the land was filled with them.

8.verse: Then a new king, who knew nothing of Joseph , came to power in Egypt.

9.verse: He said to his subjects, "Look how numerous and powerful the Israelite people are growing, more so than we ourselves!

10.verse: Come, let us deal shrewdly with them to stop their increase; otherwise, in time of war they too may join our enemies to fight against us, and so leave our country."

11.verse: Accordingly, taskmasters were set over the Israelites to oppress them with forced labor. Thus they had to build for Pharaoh the supply cities of Pithom and Raamses.

12.verse: Yet the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and spread. The Egyptians, then, dreaded the Israelites

13.verse: and reduced them to cruel slavery,

14.verse: making life bitter for them with hard work in mortar and brick and all kinds of field work - the whole cruel fate of slaves.

15.verse: The king of Egypt told the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was called Shiphrah and the other Puah,

16.verse: When you act as midwives for the Hebrew women and see them giving birth, if it is a boy, kill him; but if it is a girl, she may live."

17.verse: The midwives, however, feared God; they did not do as the king of Egypt had ordered them, but let the boys live.

18.verse: So the king summoned the midwives and asked them, "Why have you acted thus, allowing the boys to live?"

19.verse: The midwives answered Pharaoh, "The Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women. They are robust and give birth before the midwife arrives."

20.verse: Therefore God dealt well with the midwives. The people, too, increased and grew strong.

21.verse: And because the midwives feared God, he built up families for them.

22.verse: Pharaoh then commanded all his subjects, "Throw into the river every boy that is born to the Hebrews, but you may let all the girls live."

annotations.1: [1] Sons of Israel: here literally the first-generation sons of Jacob. Cf Genesis 1:5. However, beginning with Exodus 1:7 the same Hebrew phrase refers to the more remote descendants of Jacob; hence, from here on, it is ordinarily rendered "the Israelites." Households: the family in its fullest sense, including wives, children and servants
annotations.2: [2] The sons of Jacob are listed here according to the respective mothers. Cf Genesis 29:31; 30:20; 35:16-2
annotations.3: [5] Direct descendants: literally, persons coming from the loins of Jacob; hence, wives and servants are here excluded. Cf Genesis 46:2
annotations.4: [8] Who knew nothing of Joseph: this king ignored the services that Joseph had rendered to Egypt
annotations.5: [11] Pharaoh: not a personal name, but a title common to all the kings of Egypt
annotations.6: [14] Mortar: either the wet clay with which the bricks were made, as in Nahum 3:14, or the cement used between the bricks in building, as in Genesis 11:
annotations.7: [16] And see them giving birth: the Hebrew text is uncertain
annotations.8: [22] The river: the Nile, which was "the" river for the Egyptians.

1.verse: From the desert of Sin the whole Israelite community journeyed by stages, as the LORD directed, and encamped at Rephidim. Here there was no water for the people to drink.

2.verse: They quarreled, therefore, with Moses and said, "Give us water to drink." Moses replied, "Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you put the LORD to a test?"

3.verse: Here, then, in their thirst for water, the people grumbled against Moses, saying, "Why did you ever make us leave Egypt? Was it just to have us die here of thirst with our children and our livestock?"

4.verse: So Moses cried out to the LORD, "What shall I do with this people? A little more and they will stone me!"

5.verse: The LORD answered Moses, "Go over there in front of the people, along with some of the elders of Israel, holding in your hand, as you go, the staff with which you struck the river.

6.verse: I will be standing there in front of you on the rock in Horeb. Strike the rock, and the water will flow from it for the people to drink." This Moses did, in the presence of the elders of Israel.

7.verse: The place was called Massah and Meribah, because the Israelites quarreled there and tested the LORD, saying, "Is the LORD in our midst or not?"

8.verse: At Rephidim, Amalek came and waged war against Israel.

9.verse: Moses, therefore, said to Joshua, "Pick out certain men, and tomorrow go out and engage Amalek in battle. I will be standing on top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand."

10.verse: So Joshua did as Moses told him: he engaged Amalek in battle after Moses had climbed to the top of the hill with Aaron and Hur.

11.verse: As long as Moses kept his hands raised up, Israel had the better of the fight, but when he let his hands rest, Amalek had the better of the fight.

12.verse: Moses' hands, however, grew tired; so they put a rock in place for him to sit on. Meanwhile Aaron and Hur supported his hands, one on one side and one on the other, so that his hands remained steady till sunset.

13.verse: And Joshua mowed down Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword.

14.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Write this down in a document as something to be remembered, and recite it in the ears of Joshua: I will completely blot out the memory of Amalek from under the heavens."

15.verse: Moses also built an altar there, which he called Yahweh-nissi;

16.verse: for he said, "The LORD takes in hand his banner; the LORD will war against Amalek through the centuries."

annotations.1: [7] Massah . . . Meribah: Hebrew words meaning respectively, "the (place of the) test," and, "the (place of the) quarreling."
annotations.2: [8] Amalek: the Amalekites were an aboriginal people of southern Palestine and the Sinai peninsula. Cf Numbers 24:20
annotations.3: [15] Yahweh-nissi: meaning, "the LORD is my banner."

1.verse: The LORD answered him, "See! I have made you as God to Pharaoh, and Aaron your brother shall act as your prophet.

2.verse: You shall tell him all that I command you. In turn, your brother Aaron shall tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites leave his land.

3.verse: Yet I will make Pharaoh so obstinate that, despite the many signs and wonders that I will work in the land of Egypt,

4.verse: he will not listen to you. Therefore I will lay my hand on Egypt and by great acts of judgment I will bring the hosts of my people, the Israelites, out of the land of Egypt,

5.verse: so that the Egyptians may learn that I am the LORD, as I stretch out my hand against Egypt and lead the Israelites out of their midst."

6.verse: Moses and Aaron did as the LORD had commanded them.

7.verse: Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.

8.verse: The LORD told Moses and Aaron,

9.verse: "If Pharaoh demands that you work a sign or wonder, you shall say to Aaron: Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh, and it will be changed into a snake."

10.verse: Then Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did as the LORD had commanded. Aaron threw his staff down before Pharaoh and his servants, and it was changed into a snake.

11.verse: Pharaoh, in turn, summoned wise men and sorcerers, and they also, the magicians of Egypt, did likewise by their magic arts.

12.verse: Each one threw down his staff, and it was changed into a snake. But Aaron's staff swallowed their staffs.

13.verse: Pharaoh, however, was obstinate and would not listen to them, just as the LORD had foretold.

14.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Pharaoh is obdurate in refusing to let the people go.

15.verse: Tomorrow morning, when he sets out for the water, go and present yourself by the river bank, holding in your hand the staff that turned into a serpent.

16.verse: Say to him: The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, sent me to you with the message: Let my people go to worship me in the desert. But as yet you have not listened.

17.verse: The LORD now says: This is how you shall know that I am the LORD. I will strike the water of the river with the staff I hold, and it shall be changed into blood.

18.verse: The fish in the river shall die, and the river itself shall become so polluted that the Egyptians will be unable to drink its water."

19.verse: The LORD then said to Moses, "Say to Aaron: Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt - their streams and canals and pools, all their supplies of water - that they may become blood. Throughout the land of Egypt there shall be blood, even in the wooden pails and stone jars."

20.verse: Moses and Aaron did as the LORD had commanded. Aaron raised his staff and struck the waters of the river in full view of Pharaoh and his servants, and all the water of the river was changed into blood.

21.verse: The fish in the river died, and the river itself became so polluted that the Egyptians could not drink its water. There was blood throughout the land of Egypt.

22.verse: But the Egyptian magicians did the same by their magic arts. So Pharaoh remained obstinate and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the LORD had foretold.

23.verse: He turned away and went into his house, with no concern even for this.

24.verse: All the Egyptians had to dig in the neighborhood of the river for drinking water, since they could not drink the river water.

25.verse: Seven days passed after the LORD had struck the river.

26.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and tell him: Thus says the LORD: Let my people go to worship me.

27.verse: If you refuse to let them go, I warn you, I will send a plague of frogs over all your territory.

28.verse: The river will teem with frogs. They will come up into your palace and into your bedroom and onto your bed, into the houses of your servants, too, and your subjects, even into your ovens and your kneading bowls.

29.verse: The frogs will swarm all over you and your subjects and your servants."

annotations.1: [1] Just as God had his prophets to speak to men in his name, so Moses had Aaron as his "prophet" to speak to Pharaoh. Cf Exodus 4:16
annotations.2: [14] Most of the ten plagues of Egypt seem to be similar to certain natural phenomena of that country; but they are represented as supernatural at least in their greater intensity and in their occurring exactly according to Moses' commands
annotations.3: [ 7:25- 8:28] This is Exodus 8:1-32 in the verse enumeration of the Vulgate.

1.verse: "This is the rite you shall perform in consecrating them as my priests. Procure a young bull and two unblemished rams.

2.verse: With fine wheat flour make unleavened cakes mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil,

3.verse: and put them in a basket. Take the basket of them along with the bullock and the two rams.

4.verse: Aaron and his sons you shall also bring to the entrance of the meeting tent, and there wash them with water.

5.verse: Take the vestments and clothe Aaron with the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod itself, and the breastpiece, fastening the embroidered belt of the ephod around him.

6.verse: Put the miter on his head, the sacred diadem on the miter.

7.verse: Then take the anointing oil and anoint him with it, pouring it on his head.

8.verse: Bring forward his sons also and clothe them with the tunics,

9.verse: gird them with the sashes, and tie the turbans on them. Thus shall the priesthood be theirs by perpetual law, and thus shall you ordain Aaron and his sons.

10.verse: "Now bring forward the bullock in front of the meeting tent. There Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on its head.

11.verse: Then slaughter the bullock before the LORD, at the entrance of the meeting tent.

12.verse: Take some of its blood and with your finger put it on the horns of the altar. All the rest of the blood you shall pour out at the base of the altar.

13.verse: All the fat that covers its inner organs, as well as the lobe of its liver and its two kidneys, together with the fat that is on them, you shall take and burn on the altar.

14.verse: But the flesh and hide and offal of the bullock you must burn up outside the camp, since this is a sin offering.

15.verse: "Then take one of the rams, and after Aaron and his sons have laid their hands on its head,

16.verse: slaughter it. The blood you shall take and splash on all the sides of the altar.

17.verse: Cut the ram into pieces; its inner organs and shanks you shall first wash, and then put them with the pieces and with the head.

18.verse: The entire ram shall then be burned on the altar, since it is a holocaust, a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.

19.verse: "After this take the other ram, and when Aaron and his sons have laid their hands on its head,

20.verse: slaughter it. Some of its blood you shall take and put on the tip of Aaron's right ear and on the tips of his sons' right ears and on the thumbs of their right hands and the great toes of their right feet. Splash the rest of the blood on all the sides of the altar.

21.verse: Then take some of the blood that is on the altar, together with some of the anointing oil, and sprinkle this on Aaron and his vestments, as well as on his sons and their vestments, that his sons and their vestments may be sacred.

22.verse: "Now, from this ram you shall take its fat: its fatty tail, the fat that covers its inner organs, the lobe of its liver, its two kidneys with the fat that is on them, and its right thigh, since this is the ordination ram;

23.verse: then, out of the basket of unleavened food that you have set before the LORD, you shall take one of the loaves of bread, one of the cakes made with oil, and one of the wafers.

24.verse: All these things you shall put into the hands of Aaron and his sons, so that they may wave them as a wave offering before the LORD.

25.verse: After you have received them back from their hands, you shall burn them on top of the holocaust on the altar as a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.

26.verse: Finally, take the breast of Aaron's ordination ram and wave it as a wave offering before the LORD; this is to be your own portion.

27.verse: "Thus shall you set aside the breast of whatever wave offering is waved, as well as the thigh of whatever raised offering is raised up, whether this be the ordination ram or anything else belonging to Aaron or to his sons.

28.verse: Such things are due to Aaron and his sons from the Israelites by a perpetual ordinance as a contribution. From their peace offerings, too, the Israelites shall make a contribution, their contribution to the LORD.

29.verse: "The sacred vestments of Aaron shall be passed down to his descendants, that in them they may be anointed and ordained.

30.verse: The descendant who succeeds him as priest and who is to enter the meeting tent to minister in the sanctuary shall be clothed with them for seven days.

31.verse: "You shall take the flesh of the ordination ram and boil it in a holy place.

32.verse: At the entrance of the meeting tent Aaron and his sons shall eat the flesh of the ram and the bread that is in the basket.

33.verse: They themselves are to eat of these things by which atonement was made at their ordination and consecration; but no layman may eat of them, since they are sacred.

34.verse: If some of the flesh of the ordination sacrifice or some of the bread remains over on the next day, this remnant must be burned up; it is not to be eaten, since it is sacred.

35.verse: Carry out all these orders in regard to Aaron and his sons just as I have given them to you. "Seven days you shall spend in ordaining them,

36.verse: sacrificing a bullock each day as a sin offering, to make atonement. Thus also shall you purge the altar in making atonement for it; you shall anoint it in order to consecrate it.

37.verse: Seven days you shall spend in making atonement for the altar and in consecrating it. Then the altar will be most sacred, and whatever touches it will become sacred.

38.verse: "Now, this is what you shall offer on the altar: two yearling lambs as the sacrifice established for each day;

39.verse: one lamb in the morning and the other lamb at the evening twilight.

40.verse: With the first lamb there shall be a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a fourth of a hin of oil of crushed olives and, as its libation, a fourth of a hin of wine.

41.verse: The other lamb you shall offer at the evening twilight, with the same cereal offering and libation as in the morning. You shall offer this as a sweet-smelling oblation to the LORD.

42.verse: Throughout your generations this established holocaust shall be offered before the LORD at the entrance of the meeting tent, where I will meet you and speak to you.

43.verse: "There, at the altar, I will meet the Israelites; hence, it will be made sacred by my glory.

44.verse: Thus I will consecrate the meeting tent and the altar, just as I also consecrate Aaron and his sons to be my priests.

45.verse: I will dwell in the midst of the Israelites and will be their God.

46.verse: They shall know that I, the LORD, am their God who brought them out of the land of Egypt, so that I, the LORD, their God, might dwell among them.

annotations.1: [22] Fatty tail: the thick layer of fat surrounding the tails of sheep and rams bred in Palestine even today. It is regarded as a choice food. Cf Lev 3:9
annotations.2: [24-26] Wave offering: the portions of a peace offering, breast and right thigh, which the officiating priest moved to and fro (waved) in the presence of the Lord. They were reserved for Aaron and his sons
annotations.3: [27-30] These verses are a parenthetical interruption of the ordination ritual; Exodus 29:31 belongs logically immediately after Exodus 29:26
annotations.4: [36,37] Purge the altar: the construction of an altar by profane hands rendered it impure. The anointing and consecration of the altar purified it and made it sacred
annotations.5: [38-42] A parenthesis inserted into the rubrics for consecrating the altar; Exodus 29:43 belongs directly after Exodus 29:37.

1.verse: "Bezalel, therefore, will set to work with Oholiab and with all the experts whom the LORD has endowed with skill and understanding in knowing how to execute all the work for the service of the sanctuary, just as the LORD has commanded."

2.verse: Moses then called Bezalel and Oholiab and all the other experts whom the LORD had endowed with skill, men whose hearts moved them to come and take part in the work.

3.verse: They received from Moses all the contributions which the Israelites had brought for establishing the service of the sanctuary. Still, morning after morning the people continued to bring their voluntary offerings to Moses.

4.verse: Thereupon the experts who were executing the various kinds of work for the sanctuary, all left the work they were doing,

5.verse: and told Moses, "The people are bringing much more than is needed to carry out the work which the LORD has commanded us to do."

6.verse: Moses, therefore, ordered a proclamation to be made throughout the camp: "Let neither man nor woman make any more contributions for the sanctuary." So the people stopped bringing their offerings;

7.verse: there was already enough at hand, in fact, more than enough, to complete the work to be done.

8.verse: The various experts who were executing the work, made the Dwelling with its ten sheets woven of fine linen twined, having cherubim embroidered on them with violet, purple and scarlet yarn.

9.verse: The length of each sheet was twenty-eight cubits, and the width four cubits; all the sheets were of the same size.

10.verse: Five of the sheets were sewed together, edge to edge; and the same for the other five.

11.verse: Loops of violet yarn were made along the edge of the end sheet in the first set, and the same along the edge of the end sheet in the second set.

12.verse: Fifty loops were thus put on one inner sheet, and fifty loops on the inner sheet in the other set, with the loops directly opposite each other.

13.verse: Then fifty clasps of gold were made, with which the sheets were joined so that the Dwelling formed one whole.

14.verse: Sheets of goat hair were also woven as a tent over the Dwelling. Eleven such sheets were made.

15.verse: The length of each sheet was thirty cubits and the width four cubits; all eleven sheets were the same size.

16.verse: Five of these sheets were sewed edge to edge into one set; and the other six sheets into another set.

17.verse: Fifty loops were made along the edge of the end sheet in one set, and fifty loops along the edge of the corresponding sheet in the other set.

18.verse: Fifty bronze clasps were made with which the tent was joined so that it formed one whole.

19.verse: A covering for the tent was made of rams' skins dyed red, and above that, a covering of tahash skins.

20.verse: Boards of acacia wood were made as walls for the Dwelling.

21.verse: The length of each board was ten cubits, and the width one and a half cubits.

22.verse: Each board had two arms, fastening them in line. In this way all the boards of the Dwelling were made.

23.verse: They were set up as follows: twenty boards on the south side,

24.verse: with forty silver pedestals under the twenty boards, so that there were two pedestals under each board, at its two arms;

25.verse: twenty boards on the other side of the Dwelling, the north side,

26.verse: with their forty silver pedestals, two under each board;

27.verse: six boards at the rear of the Dwelling, to the west;

28.verse: and two boards at the corners in the rear of the Dwelling.

29.verse: These were double at the bottom, and likewise double at the top, to the first ring. That is how both boards in the corners were made.

30.verse: Thus, there were in the rear eight boards, with their sixteen silver pedestals, two pedestals under each board.

31.verse: Bars of acacia wood were also made, five for the boards on one side of the Dwelling,

32.verse: five for those on the other side, and five for those at the rear, to the west.

33.verse: The center bar, at the middle of the boards, was made to reach across from end to end.

34.verse: The boards were plated with gold, and gold rings were made on them as holders for the bars, which were also plated with gold.

35.verse: The veil was woven of violet, purple and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, with cherubim embroidered on it.

36.verse: Four gold-plated columns of acacia wood, with gold hooks, were made for it, and four silver pedestals were cast for them.

37.verse: The curtain for the entrance of the tent was made of violet, purple and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, woven in a variegated manner.

38.verse: Its five columns, with their hooks as well as their capitals and bands, were plated with gold; their five pedestals were of bronze.

1.verse: This is what the LORD then said to Moses:

2.verse: "Tell the Israelites to take up a collection for me. From every man you shall accept the contribution that his heart prompts him to give me.

3.verse: These are the contributions you shall accept from them: gold, silver and bronze;

4.verse: violet, purple and scarlet yarn; fine linen and goat hair;

5.verse: rams' skins dyed red, and tahash skins; acacia wood;

6.verse: oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;

7.verse: onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and the breastpiece.

8.verse: "They shall make a sanctuary for me, that I may dwell in their midst.

9.verse: This Dwelling and all its furnishings you shall make exactly according to the pattern that I will now show you.

10.verse: "You shall make an ark of acacia wood, two and a half cubits long, one and a half cubits wide, and one and a half cubits high.

11.verse: Plate it inside and outside with pure gold, and put a molding of gold around the top of it.

12.verse: Cast four gold rings and fasten them on the four supports of the ark, two rings on one side and two on the opposite side.

13.verse: Then make poles of acacia wood and plate them with gold.

14.verse: These poles you are to put through the rings on the sides of the ark, for carrying it;

15.verse: they must remain in the rings of the ark and never be withdrawn.

16.verse: In the ark you are to put the commandments which I will give you.

17.verse: "You shall then make a propitiatory of pure gold, two cubits and a half long, and one and a half cubits wide.

18.verse: Make two cherubim of beaten gold for the two ends of the propitiatory,

19.verse: fastening them so that one cherub springs direct from each end.

20.verse: The cherubim shall have their wings spread out above, covering the propitiatory with them; they shall be turned toward each other, but with their faces looking toward the propitiatory.

21.verse: This propitiatory you shall then place on top of the ark. In the ark itself you are to put the commandments which I will give you.

22.verse: There I will meet you and there, from above the propitiatory, between the two cherubim on the ark of the commandments, I will tell you all the commands that I wish you to give the Israelites.

23.verse: "You shall also make a table of acacia wood, two cubits long, a cubit wide, and a cubit and a half high.

24.verse: Plate it with pure gold and make a molding of gold around it.

25.verse: Surround it with a frame, a handbreadth high, with a molding of gold around the frame.

26.verse: You shall also make four rings of gold for it and fasten them at the four corners, one at each leg,

27.verse: on two opposite sides of the frame as holders for the poles to carry the table.

28.verse: These poles for carrying the table you shall make of acacia wood and plate with gold.

29.verse: Of pure gold you shall make its plates and cups, as well as its pitchers and bowls for pouring libations.

30.verse: On the table you shall always keep showbread set before me.

31.verse: "You shall make a lampstand of pure beaten gold - its shaft and branches - with its cups and knobs and petals springing directly from it.

32.verse: Six branches are to extend from the sides of the lampstand, three branches on one side, and three on the other.

33.verse: On one branch there are to be three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; on the opposite branch there are to be three cups, shaped like almond blossoms, each with its knob and petals; and so for the six branches that extend from the lampstand.

34.verse: On the shaft there are to be four cups, shaped like almond blossoms, with their knobs and petals,

35.verse: including a knob below each of the three pairs of branches that extend from the lampstand.

36.verse: Their knobs and branches shall so spring from it that the whole will form but a single piece of pure beaten gold.

37.verse: You shall then make seven lamps for it and so set up the lamps that they shed their light on the space in front of the lampstand.

38.verse: These, as well as the trimming shears and trays, must be of pure gold.

39.verse: Use a talent of pure gold for the lampstand and all its appurtenances.

40.verse: See that you make them according to the pattern shown you on the mountain.

annotations.1: [5] Tahash: perhaps the name of a marine animal, such as the dugong or the porpoise. The Greek and Latin versions took it for the color hyacinth
annotations.2: [17] Propitiatory: this traditional rendering of the Hebrew term, which may mean merely "cover," is derived from its connection with the ceremony of the Day of Atonement whereby God was rendered "propitious." Cf Lev 16:14, 16
annotations.3: [18-20] Cherubim: probably in the form of human-headed winged lions. The cherubim over the ark formed the throne for the invisible Lord. Cf Psalm 80:2. For a more detailed description of the somewhat different cherubim in the temple of Solomon, see 1 Kings 6:23-28; 2 Chron 3:10-13
annotations.4: [25] A frame: probably placed near the bottom of the legs to keep them steady. The golden table of Herod's temple is pictured thus on the Arch of Titus
annotations.5: [29-30] The plates held the showbread, that is, the holy bread which was placed upon the table every sabbath as an offering to God, and was later eaten by the priests. The cups held the incense which was strewn upon the bread. Cf Lev 24:5-9. The libation wine was poured from the pitchers into the bowls. All these vessels were kept on the golden table
annotations.6: [33] In keeping with the arrangement of the ornaments on the shaft, the three sets of ornaments on each branch were probably so placed that one was at the top and the other two equally spaced along the length of the branch. Knob: the cup-shaped seed capsule at the base of a flower
annotations.7: [34-35] Of the four ornaments on the shaft, one was at the top and one was below each of the three sets of side branches
annotations.8: [37] The lamps were probably shaped like small boats, with the wick at one end; the end with the wick was turned toward the front of the lampstand
annotations.9: [38] Trays: small receptacles for the burnt-out wicks.

1.verse: With violet, purple and scarlet yarn were woven the service cloths for use in the sanctuary, as well as the sacred vestments for Aaron, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

2.verse: The ephod was woven of gold thread and of violet, purple and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined.

3.verse: Gold was first hammered into gold leaf and then cut up into threads, which were woven with the violet, purple and scarlet yarn into an embroidered pattern on the fine linen.

4.verse: Shoulder straps were made for it and joined to its two upper ends.

5.verse: The embroidered belt on the ephod extended out from it, and like it, was made of gold thread, of violet, purple and scarlet yarn, and of fine linen twined, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

6.verse: The onyx stones were prepared and mounted in gold filigree work; they were engraved like seal engravings with the names of the sons of Israel.

7.verse: These stones were set on the shoulder straps of the ephod as memorial stones of the sons of Israel, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

8.verse: The breastpiece was embroidered like the ephod, with gold thread and violet, purple and scarlet yarn on cloth of fine linen twined.

9.verse: It was square and folded double, a span high and a span wide in its folded form.

10.verse: Four rows of precious stones were mounted on it: in the first row a carnelian, a topaz and an emerald;

11.verse: in the second row, a garnet, a sapphire and a beryl;

12.verse: in the third row a jacinth, an agate and an amethyst;

13.verse: in the fourth row a chrysolite, an onyx and a jasper. They were mounted in gold filigree work.

14.verse: These stones were twelve, to match the names of the sons of Israel, and each stone was engraved like a seal with the name of one of the twelve tribes.

15.verse: Chains of pure gold, twisted like cords, were made for the breastpiece,

16.verse: together with two gold filigree rosettes and two gold rings. The two rings were fastened to the two upper ends of the breastpiece.

17.verse: The two gold chains were then fastened to the two rings at the ends of the breastpiece.

18.verse: The other two ends of the two chains were fastened in front to the two filigree rosettes, which were attached to the shoulder straps of the ephod.

19.verse: Two other gold rings were made and put on the two lower ends of the breastpiece, on the edge facing the ephod.

20.verse: Two more gold rings were made and fastened to the bottom of the two shoulder straps next to where they joined the ephod in front, just above its embroidered belt.

21.verse: Violet ribbons bound the rings of the breastpiece to the rings of the ephod, so that the breastpiece stayed right above the embroidered belt of the ephod and did not swing loose from it. All this was just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

22.verse: The robe of the ephod was woven entirely of violet yarn,

23.verse: with an opening in its center like the opening of a shirt, with selvage around the opening to keep it from being torn.

24.verse: At the hem of the robe pomegranates were made of violet, purple and scarlet yarn and of fine linen twined;

25.verse: bells of pure gold were also made and put between the pomegranates all around the hem of the robe:

26.verse: first a bell, then a pomegranate, and thus alternating all around the hem of the robe which was to be worn in performing the ministry - all this, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

27.verse: For Aaron and his sons there were also woven tunics of fine linen;

28.verse: the miter of fine linen; the ornate turbans of fine linen; drawers of linen (of fine linen twined);

29.verse: and sashes of variegated work made of fine linen twined and of violet, purple and scarlet yarn, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

30.verse: The plate of the sacred diadem was made of pure gold and inscribed, as on a seal engraving: "Sacred to the LORD."

31.verse: It was tied over the miter with a violet ribbon, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

32.verse: Thus the entire work of the Dwelling of the meeting tent was completed. The Israelites did the work just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

33.verse: They then brought to Moses the Dwelling, the tent with all its appurtenances, the clasps, the boards, the bars, the columns, the pedestals,

34.verse: the covering of rams' skins dyed red, the covering of tahash skins, the curtain veil;

35.verse: the ark of the commandments with its poles, the propitiatory,

36.verse: the table with all its appurtenances and the showbread,

37.verse: the pure gold lampstand with its lamps set up on it and with all its appurtenances, the oil for the light,

38.verse: the golden altar, the anointing oil, the fragrant incense; the curtain for the entrance of the tent,

39.verse: the altar of bronze with its bronze grating, its poles and all its appurtenances, the laver with its base,

40.verse: the hangings of the court with their columns and pedestals, the curtain for the entrance of the court with its ropes and tent pegs, all the equipment for the service of the Dwelling of the meeting tent;

41.verse: the service cloths for use in the sanctuary, the sacred vestments for Aaron the priest, and the vestments to be worn by his sons in their ministry.

42.verse: The Israelites had carried out all the work just as the LORD had commanded Moses.

43.verse: So when Moses saw that all the work was done just as the LORD had commanded, he blessed them.

1.verse: Moses assembled the whole Israelite community and said to them, "This is what the LORD has commanded to be done.

2.verse: On six days work may be done, but the seventh day shall be sacred to you as the sabbath of complete rest to the LORD. Anyone who does work on that day shall be put to death.

3.verse: You shall not even light a fire in any of your dwellings on the sabbath day."

4.verse: Moses told the whole Israelite community, "This is what the LORD has commanded:

5.verse: Take up among you a collection for the LORD. Everyone, as his heart prompts him, shall bring, as a contribution to the LORD, gold, silver and bronze;

6.verse: violet, purple and scarlet yarn; fine linen and goat hair;

7.verse: rams' skins dyed red, and tahash skins; acacia wood;

8.verse: oil for the light; spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense;

9.verse: onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and on the breastpiece.

10.verse: "Let every expert among you come and make all that the LORD has commanded: the Dwelling,

11.verse: with its tent, its covering, its clasps, its boards, its bars, its columns and its pedestals;

12.verse: the ark, with its poles, the propitiatory, and the curtain veil;

13.verse: the table, with its poles and all its appurtenances, and the showbread;

14.verse: the lampstand, with its appurtenances, the lamps, and the oil for the light;

15.verse: the altar of incense, with its poles; the anointing oil, and the fragrant incense; the entrance curtain for the entrance of the Dwelling;

16.verse: the altar of holocausts, with its bronze grating, its poles, and all its appurtenances; the laver, with its base;

17.verse: the hangings of the court, with their columns and pedestals; the curtain for the entrance of the court;

18.verse: the tent pegs for the Dwelling and for the court, with their ropes;

19.verse: the service cloths for use in the sanctuary; the sacred vestments for Aaron, the priest, and the vestments worn by his sons in their ministry."

20.verse: When the whole Israelite community left Moses' presence,

21.verse: everyone, as his heart suggested and his spirit prompted, brought a contribution to the LORD for the construction of the meeting tent, for all its services, and for the sacred vestments.

22.verse: Both the men and the women, all as their heart prompted them, brought brooches, earrings, rings, necklaces and various other gold articles. Everyone who could presented an offering of gold to the LORD.

23.verse: Everyone who happened to have violet, purple or scarlet yarn, fine linen or goat hair, rams' skins dyed red or tahash skins, brought them.

24.verse: Whoever could make a contribution of silver or bronze offered it to the LORD; and everyone who happened to have acacia wood for any part of the work, brought it.

25.verse: All the women who were expert spinners brought hand-spun violet, purple and scarlet yarn and fine linen thread.

26.verse: All the women who possessed the skill, spun goat hair.

27.verse: The princes brought onyx stones and other gems for mounting on the ephod and on the breastpiece;

28.verse: as well as spices, and oil for the light, anointing oil, and fragrant incense.
